Subject: English
TopicInvitationDescription: Another way of cataloguing these topics was to consider the invitation they offered students. This may include, but is not restricted to, topics that:

Subject: English
TopicInvitationExplanation:
A topic might ask students to consider two or more concepts and the validity of a specified relationship between the terms.
Responses can challenge the relationship but must address the ideas presented by the author in relation to the nominated concepts.
TopicInvitationExample:
‘Tell her your story – I mean your own story.’
Requiem for a Beast suggests that shared stories are vital for connecting people and communities.
Discuss.

Subject: English
TopicInvitationDefinition: Drill into a specific aspect of a concept presented by the text
TopicInvitationExplanation: A topic might ask students to ‘drill into’ a concept presented in a text and discuss one (or more) specified aspect(s) of the concept.
TopicInvitationExample:
In Oedipus the King all who deserve it are justly punished.
Do you agree?

Subject: English
TopicInvitationDefinition: Consideration of concept/idea development in the text
TopicInvitationExplanation: Students might be asked how a concept/idea was explored in a text both by discussing the way ideas were introduced and developed and by exploring the way in which they were conveyed by the author.
TopicInvitationExample: How does Ottley explore the power of both guilt and forgiveness?
